text: And Lot went out, and spake unto his sons in law, which married his daughters, and said, Up, get you out of this place; for the LORD will destroy this city. But he seemed as one that mocked unto his sons in law.
text_kjv: And Lot went out, and spake unto his sons in law, which married his daughters, and said, Up, get you out of this place; for the LORD will destroy this city. But he seemed as one that mocked unto his sons in law.
text_niv: So Lot went out and spoke to his sons-in-law, who were pledged to marry his daughters. He said, “Hurry and get out of this place, because the Lord is about to destroy the city!” But his sons-in-law thought he was joking.
text_esv: So Lot went out and said to his sons-in-law, who were to marry his daughters, “Up! Get out of this place, for the LORD is about to destroy the city.” But he seemed to his sons-in-law to be jesting.
text_nlt: So Lot rushed out to tell his daughters’ fiancés, “Quick, get out of the city! The LORD is about to destroy it.” But the young men thought he was only joking.
text_msg: Lot went out and warned the fianc-s of his daughters, "Evacuate this place; God is about to destroy this city!" But his daughters' would-be husbands treated it as a joke.
text_nasb: Lot went out and spoke to his sons-in-law, who were to marry his daughters, and said, 'Up, get out of this place, for the LORD will destroy the city.' But he appeared to his sons-in-law to be jesting.
context: Genesis 19 unfolds against the backdrop of deep-seated societal corruption in Sodom. Understanding the socio-cultural context is crucial. Marriage arrangements in ancient Near Eastern societies, including Lot's, were often strategic alliances, not necessarily based on romantic love. 'Sons-in-law' could refer to betrothed men, not necessarily those already married. Betrothal was a legally binding agreement. Sodom's wickedness, particularly its blatant disregard for hospitality and its embrace of homosexual practices (as understood by the narrative), offended ancient Near Eastern values which prized kinship, community and treatment of strangers as honored guests. Furthermore, the concept of divine judgment and collective punishment was common. A community's sin could bring destruction upon the entire group. Angels appearing as men tested the city's moral fiber, highlighting its irredeemable state. Lot's status as a resident alien made him vulnerable, yet Abraham's intercession bought him time and the opportunity for escape. Lot's own compromised integration into Sodom's society, evidenced by his willingness to offer his daughters to the mob in the previous chapter, further complicates the narrative. His delayed departure and reluctance to leave reflect this divided loyalty. The city's reputation for immorality likely extended beyond just sexual sin and likely included dishonest business practices, disregard for the poor, and widespread violence.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 19:14 presents a sobering picture of disbelief and the rejection of divine warnings. Lot, acting as God's messenger, attempts to convey the imminent destruction of Sodom to his sons-in-law. Their reaction, however, is to dismiss him as someone joking or 'mocking.' This highlights the blindness caused by sin and the human tendency to resist uncomfortable truths, especially those that challenge deeply ingrained lifestyles or beliefs. The verse underscores the severity of Sodom's wickedness. Its corruption was so pervasive that even the promise of divine judgment failed to elicit repentance or even a sense of urgency. The sons-in-law's disbelief speaks to the hardening of hearts and the consequences of prolonged exposure to immorality. Furthermore, the verse raises questions about the effectiveness of Lot's witness. His compromised life in Sodom likely diminished his credibility. His own choices to live in a sinful environment undermined his ability to persuade others of the danger they faced. God’s justice is revealed in the impending destruction, but also His mercy in sending a warning. Yet, humans have free will to choose to heed the warning or reject it. This verse acts as a microcosm of the larger narrative of salvation history – God's provision of warning and redemption, and humanity's frequent refusal to accept it.
application: Genesis 19:14 provides several profound applications for modern living. First, it challenges us to examine our own responses to warnings, both from God and from trusted sources. Are we open to correction, or do we dismiss uncomfortable truths as 'mockery'? Second, it reminds us of the importance of credible witness. Our lives must align with our words if we hope to influence others for good. Living a compromised life, as Lot did, diminishes our ability to effectively share the truth. Third, it underscores the pervasive nature of sin. Sin can blind us to the consequences of our actions and harden our hearts to the voice of God. We must be vigilant against the insidious influence of sin in our own lives and in the wider culture. Fourth, this verse calls us to consider the potential judgment that awaits those who reject God's grace. While we should not delight in the prospect of judgment, we must acknowledge its reality. Fifth, the verse encourages us to actively share the gospel with those around us, even when our message is met with skepticism or rejection. Like Lot, we may face ridicule, but we must remain faithful to our calling. Pray for discernment in these situations. Consider how you are perceived by those you wish to influence. Are you seen as authentic and trustworthy? Reflect on areas in your life where you may be compromising your values. Finally, be sensitive to the 'Sodom's' in our own societies and cultures, and stand against injustice and immorality wherever we find it.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive us for the times we have dismissed Your warnings as foolishness. Open our eyes to the truth, even when it is uncomfortable. Help us to live lives of integrity, so that our words will carry weight and credibility. Give us the courage to speak out against injustice and immorality, even when it is unpopular. Soften the hearts of those who are blinded by sin, and draw them to Yourself. Grant us discernment to know when to speak and when to be silent. Fill us with compassion for those who are lost and struggling. Remind us daily of Your grace and mercy, and help us to extend that same grace and mercy to others. Give us wisdom to navigate this world while holding tightly to your truth. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: They likely found Lot's warning unbelievable due to their deep immersion in Sodom's immoral culture. Prolonged exposure to sin can desensitize individuals, making them resistant to warnings of judgment. Also, Lot's own compromised lifestyle may have undermined his credibility with them.
faqs.question: Q1: Why did Lot's sons-in-law think he was joking?

faqs.answer: This verse reveals that sin can blind individuals to the truth and harden their hearts. It demonstrates how pervasive immorality can desensitize people to the consequences of their actions and make them dismissive of divine warnings.
faqs.question: Q2: What does this verse teach us about the nature of sin?

faqs.answer: To avoid being like Lot's sons-in-law, we must cultivate humility, remaining open to correction and willing to examine our own lives in light of God's Word. We should avoid prolonged exposure to harmful influences and surround ourselves with godly influences.
faqs.question: Q3: How can we avoid being like Lot's sons-in-law?

faqs.answer: Effective gospel sharing requires a combination of prayer, a credible lifestyle, and clear communication. We must live out our faith authentically, pray for those we are trying to reach, and clearly articulate the message of salvation with grace and truth.
